paper_abstract: Let f (n, k) be the minimum number of edges that must be removed from some complete geometric graph G on n points, so that there exists a tree on k vertices that is no longer a planar subgraph of G. In this paper we show that (1/2) n(2)/k-1 - n/2 <= f (n, k) <= 2 n(n-2)/k/2. For the case when k - n, we show that 2 <= f (n, n) <= 3. For the case when k = n and G is a geometric graph on a set of points in convex position, we completely solve the problem and prove that at least three edges must be removed.
paper_title: The Erdos-Sos Conjecture for Geometric Graphs
